Award.AwardTitle: Development of the Himalayan Superstructure, Northwestern India
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research seeks to determine the structural evolution of the Himalayan superstructure from the India-Asia suture zone to the deformed foreland. The term 'superstructure' refers to the low-grade upper level of an orogenic system, and contrasts with high-grade 'infrastructure' below. Along most of the Himalayan arc, superstructure rocks are only partially preserved. They occur in the north, but high-grade crystalline rocks occupy a central swath and recently accreted material dominates exposures farther south. However, across the eastern Ladakh - Chamba region of the northwestern Indian Himalaya, superstructure rocks are continuously exposed from the suture zone to the foreland fold-thrust belt. The deformation record preserved in these rocks can be used to address two problems: (1) long-standing controversy over the mechanism that emplaced infrastructure rocks between superstructure rocks and accreted materials, and (2) recent recognition that the Himalayan rock record may preserve far less shortening than that required by plate circuit reconstructions. These issues will be addressed by a research program combining mapping, analytical work, and reconstruction. Surface and remote sensing geological mapping using ASTER data will establish the geological framework across the eastern Ladakh - Chamba superstructure. These results will be complemented by kinematic analysis obtained via microstructural studies and thermal history determined via 40Ar/39Ar geo/thermochronology. New and existing structural, thermal, and chronological data will be integrated via balanced palinspastic reconstruction to explore deformation modes and determine shortening estimates, thereby providing a deformation history capable of testing extrusion models and a revised geological shortening budget to test shortening models. Preliminary analysis suggests that this work may add nearly 500 kilometers to the Himalayan shortening budget, which would represent a greater than 50% increase in preserved geological shortening.

Mountain-building processes are commonly explored across systems with ongoing contraction such as the Alps, Andes, and Himalaya. These mountain belts offer good preservation, direct constraints on boundary conditions, and the opportunity to simultaneously interrogate ancient and active deformation. The community of tectonics workers is still working out the regional geometry and kinematics of many parts of these systems, particularly along-strike structural variations. The incompleteness of our first-order knowledge of the Himalaya is highlighted by recent studies of the Himalaya that propose a variety of radical revisions to our understanding of initial India-Asia collision and the emplacement of its high-grade crystalline core. The current project will help address both issues by utilizing an under-explored aspect of the range: the local preservation of a wide span of its lower grade carapace rocks in the western Himalaya. By exploring the deformation history of these rocks, this study is anticipated to provide strong limits on Himalayan kinematic models. Broader impacts of this work include training of a Ph.D. student from an underrepresented group, as well as providing research experience for as many as six undergraduate students. The research team will continue outreach activities to communicate tectonics to broad audiences locally, and internationally through creation of Wikipedia pages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Questions and Goals

We tested two sets of ideas for how the Himalayan mountains have been built during the last ~50 million years. All workers agree that the Himalaya is built as India slides beneath Asia, such that the mountains have been built as Asia scrapes off rocks from upper portions of the Indian plate. Beyond this general agreement, major questions lurk. 

First, the architecture of the Himalaya is, in some senses, simple: it can be generalized as three layers stacked one atop another, separated by faults. However, the development of this simple layering remains uncertain. Some hypotheses involve the extrusion of the high-grade middle layer to the surface between two surface-breaching faults. Strictly in terms of motion (not mechanics), this would be akin to trying to hold a pumpkin seed between your fingers - these tend to be slippery and "extrude" out from between your fingers. Other ideas involve progressive scraping and stacking of Indian crustal material into a pile built from the bottom up, similar to how sand piles up in front of an advancing bulldozer. We sought to test these different concepts.

Second, some paleomagnetism workers have suggested that the Himalaya experienced more convergence of India and Asia than it managed to record by piling up of scraped off materials. They posit that the difference in convergence vs. shortening records is so large (~500-2500 km in various portions of the range) that it can only be explained by subduction of a large ocean basin during the period that most prior workers have thought as the middle period of the Indian underthrusting phases. [Subduction of ocean basins are thought to leave only sparse shortening records, whereas collision of continents should leave rich shortening records]. We sought evidence for this proposed ocean basin, and to improve our understanding of the shortening records that the hypothesis relies upon.

Significance of Research Questions

Why might these questions be important? In a broad sense, the Himalaya represent what geologists often refer to as our "natural laboratory of continent-continent collisional processes". Much of our understanding of mountain-building, particularly the ancient collisional orogens that built the east coast of the United States from Texas to Maine (and beyond, of course), is based on comparative analysis of the Himalayan mountain building. Therefore, our understanding of our own continent's formation is in some respects only as good as our understanding of the Himalayan mountain building. 

The big outstanding question in much of our understanding of the Himalaya, and elsewhere, is the role of interactions between climate, erosion, and tectonics in forming the mountains. The last 25 years of research have left little doubt that climate - tectonics interactions, modulated through erosion, make profound impacts on million-year time-scale evolution of the solid Earth, the atmosphere, and the oceans... and thus on life via all of its settings. Nonetheless these interactions can be complex, sometimes involving non-linear feedbacks, and chicken-and-egg problems are common. Himalayan extrusion models are a case in point - in these models, a climatic shift enhances erosion, which in turn forces the extrusion of high grade rocks and the uplift of the mountains. However, the most likely mechanism to cause the climatic shift is changing topography - a response to the uplift of mountains.  

Research Approach

The extrusion models predict a continuous band of high-grade rocks along the length of the Himalaya, so we undertook detailed exploration across a region where early findings suggested no such rocks occur. In doing so, we speculated that we would have access to rocks high in the Himalayan stratigraphy, which would provide some of the most detailed shortening records and permit new analysis of the total Himalayan shortening budget.  

Research Findings

We confirmed through field mapping and analytical results that in the northwestern Indian Himalaya, a continuous span of low-grade rocks extends from the northern limit of the Himalaya (where rocks scraped from India are juxtaposed against Asian rocks) to the southern edge of the range. This rules out extrusion models for this range sector, suggesting that other mechanisms of climate-erosion-tectonics have formed the range. The shortening recorded in this range sector nearly matches the shortening suggested via paleomagnetic work, so a mid-collisional ocean basin is not required here. 

Key Advance

We stumbled upon a significant finding: key tectonic events in our relatively western study area were completed as many as ~10 million years prior to similar developments in the east-central Himalaya, with progressive shifts in timing across the intervening areas. No current hypothesis explains why: all of our models are 2D along cross sections perpendicular to the range (parallel to the collision direction). We made a 3D model to start the conversation, speculating that a break in the down-going Indian plate might migrate along the length of the range, changing tectonics laterally as it propagates.
